column1: [Original - Section 6.1] Let f(x) = {1/(x-2), if x > 2; x², if -2 ≤ x ≤ 2; 3, if x < -2}. Evaluate the following: (i) f(-5) (ii) f(-2) (iii) f(0) (iv) f(1) (v) f(2) (vi) f(3).
column2: Solution: We evaluate the function by determining which piece applies for each input value. (i) f(-5): Since -5 < -2, we use the third piece: f(-5) = 3. (ii) f(-2): Since -2 = -2, we use the second piece: f(-2) = (-2)² = 4. (iii) f(0): Since -2 < 0 ≤ 2, we use the second piece: f(0) = 0² = 0. (iv) f(1): Since -2 < 1 ≤ 2, we use the second piece: f(1) = 1² = 1. (v) f(2): Since -2 < 2 ≤ 2, we use the second piece: f(2) = 2² = 4. (vi) f(3): Since 3 > 2, we use the first piece: f(3) = 1/(3-2) = 1/1 = 1.

column1: [Variation] Let g(x) = {x² + 1, if x < 0; 2x - 3, if 0 ≤ x < 3; √x, if x ≥ 3}. Find the values of: (i) g(-2) (ii) g(0) (iii) g(1) (iv) g(3) (v) g(4).
column2: Solution: We determine which piece of the function applies for each input value. (i) g(-2): Since -2 < 0, we use the first piece: g(-2) = (-2)² + 1 = 4 + 1 = 5. (ii) g(0): Since 0 ≥ 0 and 0 < 3, we use the second piece: g(0) = 2(0) - 3 = -3. (iii) g(1): Since 0 ≤ 1 < 3, we use the second piece: g(1) = 2(1) - 3 = -1. (iv) g(3): Since 3 ≥ 3, we use the third piece: g(3) = √3 ≈ 1.732. (v) g(4): Since 4 > 3, we use the third piece: g(4) = √4 = 2.

column1: [Original - Section 6.1] Find the difference quotient (f(a+h) - f(a))/h if f(x) = 1/x².
column2: Solution: We compute each component and then assemble the difference quotient. f(a+h) = 1/(a+h)². f(a) = 1/a². (f(a+h) - f(a))/h = (1/(a+h)² - 1/a²)/h = (a² - (a+h)²)/(h·a²·(a+h)²) = (a² - a² - 2ah - h²)/(h·a²·(a+h)²) = (-2ah - h²)/(h·a²·(a+h)²) = (-2a - h)/(a²·(a+h)²). As h approaches 0, this approaches -2a/(a²·a²) = -2/a³.

column1: [Variation] Calculate the difference quotient (f(x+h) - f(x))/h for the function f(x) = 3x² - 2x + 1, and determine what this expression approaches as h approaches 0.
column2: Solution: First, we find f(x+h) and f(x): f(x+h) = 3(x+h)² - 2(x+h) + 1 = 3(x² + 2xh + h²) - 2x - 2h + 1 = 3x² + 6xh + 3h² - 2x - 2h + 1. f(x) = 3x² - 2x + 1. (f(x+h) - f(x))/h = (3x² + 6xh + 3h² - 2x - 2h + 1 - 3x² + 2x - 1)/h = (6xh + 3h² - 2h)/h = 6x + 3h - 2. As h approaches 0, this approaches 6x - 2, which is the derivative f(x).

column1: [Original - Section 6.2] Sketch the graph of f(x) = {1, if x ≤ 0; x², if 0 < x < 1; 1/x, if x ≥ 1}.
column2: Solution: We analyze each piece of the function: For x ≤ 0: f(x) = 1, which is a horizontal line at y = 1 for all negative x values. For 0 < x < 1: f(x) = x², which is a portion of a parabola. At x = 0, the limit from the right is 0, creating a discontinuity. For x ≥ 1: f(x) = 1/x, which is a hyperbola. At x = 1, both pieces give f(1) = 1, so the function is continuous at x = 1. The function has a jump discontinuity at x = 0.

column1: [Variation] Sketch the graph of g(x) = {|x|, if x < 0; sin(πx/2), if 0 ≤ x ≤ 2; 4-x, if x > 2}. Identify any discontinuities.
column2: Solution: Analyzing each piece of the function: For x < 0: g(x) = |x| = -x, which is a line with slope -1 for negative x values. For 0 ≤ x ≤ 2: g(x) = sin(πx/2), which is half a period of the sine function. At x = 0, g(0) = sin(0) = 0, and |0| = 0, so the function is continuous at x = 0. For x > 2: g(x) = 4-x, which is a line with slope -1. At x = 2, g(2) = sin(π) = 0, but 4-2 = 2, creating a discontinuity. The function has a jump discontinuity at x = 2.

column1: [Original - Section 6.2] Using the graph of f(x), determine the intervals where f is increasing or decreasing. Also, determine any local maximum points or local minimum points.
column2: Solution: From the graph, we can see that f(x) is increasing on the interval (-∞, 0) and decreasing on the interval (0, ∞). The function has a local maximum at x = 0, where the function changes from increasing to decreasing. There are no local minimum points visible on the graph.

column1: [Variation] For the function f(x) = x³ - 6x² + 9x + 1, find the critical points and determine the intervals where the function is increasing or decreasing. Identify all local maxima and minima.
column2: Solution: To find critical points, we set f(x) = 0: f(x) = 3x² - 12x + 9 = 3(x² - 4x + 3) = 3(x - 1)(x - 3) = 0. So x = 1 or x = 3 are critical points. Testing intervals: For x < 1, f(x) > 0, so f is increasing. For 1 < x < 3, f(x) < 0, so f is decreasing. For x > 3, f(x) > 0, so f is increasing. Therefore, f has a local maximum at x = 1 and a local minimum at x = 3.

column1: [Original - Section 6.5] Let f(x) = x² and g(x) = 1/(x-4). Determine the following compositions and their domains: (i) (f∘g)(x) (ii) (g∘f)(x) (iii) (f∘f)(x) (iv) (g∘g)(x).
[Variation] Let f(x) = 3x² - 1 and g(x) = √(x+4). Find the following compositions and their domains: (i) (f∘g)(x) (ii) (g∘f)(x) (iii) (f∘f)(x) (iv) (g∘g)(x).
column2: Solution: (i) (f∘g)(x) = f(g(x)) = f(√(x+4)) = 3(√(x+4))² - 1 = 3(x+4) - 1 = 3x + 12 - 1 = 3x + 11. Domain: x ≥ -4 or [-4, ∞). (ii) (g∘f)(x) = g(f(x)) = g(3x² - 1) = √((3x² - 1) + 4) = √(3x² + 3). Domain: 3x² + 3 ≥ 0, which is true for all real numbers, so domain is (-∞, ∞). (iii) (f∘f)(x) = f(f(x)) = f(3x² - 1) = 3(3x² - 1)² - 1 = 3(9x⁴ - 6x² + 1) - 1 = 27x⁴ - 18x² + 3 - 1 = 27x⁴ - 18x² + 2. Domain: All real numbers or (-∞, ∞). (iv) (g∘g)(x) = g(g(x)) = g(√(x+4)) = √(√(x+4) + 4). Domain: x ≥ -4 or [-4, ∞).

column1: [Original - Section 6.5] Let f(x) = 1/(x-2) and g(x) = x² + 3. Find: (i) (f∘g)(x) and its domain (ii) (g∘f)(x) and its domain (iii) The value of (f∘g)(1) (iv) The value of (g∘f)(0).
[Variation] Let f(x) = 2x - 5 and g(x) = x³. Determine: (i) (f∘g)(x) and its domain (ii) (g∘f)(x) and its domain (iii) The value of (f∘g)(2) (iv) The value of (g∘f)(-1).
